position.marginalia_text: utriq[ue] historiae, tam exterae, quam Romanae accommodata praefatio. Rerum Romanarum mei primi historici, Aurelius Victor. Eutropius. Livius. Exterarum rerum, Justinus, Aemilius Probus, maximam partem Polyaenus. Utrisq[ue] valde conducunt Florus, Frontinus, Velleius, Valerius Maximus, Plutarchus. Quibus etiam propter res neotericas adiungo Egnatium, Gandinum, Jovium, Guicciardinum. Omninoq[ue] Zuingerum. Nullos praetermitto signiferos, nec Graecos, nec Latinos, nec vernaculos: sed insisto singulis, mea quadam ad communem, propriumque usum singulari methodo. Nec istam Romanaru[m], exterarumq[ue] rerum discriminationem, ullus adhuc, quod sciam, Polyhistor, satis accurate est meditatus. Interest politici, hanc distinctionem subtilius decidere: et tot Rerumpublicaru[m] historicos solertiori iudicio examinare.

marginalia.translation: This preface is also commonly attached to Justin, as it is suitable for each kind of history, both foreign and Roman. My leading historians for Roman matters are Aurelius Victor, Eutropius, and Livy. For foreign matters: Justin, Aemilius Probus and, to the largest extent, Polyaenus. Florus, Frontinus, Velleius, Valerius Maximus and Plutarch are very expedient for both kinds. And to these I add Egnatius, Gandinus, Giovio, Guicciardini for modern issues, and absolutely Zwinger. I do not leave out any important one, either Greek, Latin, or vernacular, but I devote myself to particular ones, with my own specific method for general and private use. And to my knowledge no polyhistor so far has ever reflected in sufficient detail upon this distinction between Roman and foreign matters. It is important for a politician to mark this difference very accurately and to analyze the historians of all these Republics with a very skillful judgment.
